												Well, what is Divine Divinity?It is the prove that a hack&slay-style gameplay doesn't mean that you can't have a deep and long story with true roleplaying. It is the prove that choosing a class for your character in an rpg doesn't need to limit your further character development. It is the prove that you can have story, the freedom of choice, open world AND action in one game. And it is the prove that mad magicians can invent words even imps can't pronounce properly...Well, Divine Divinity is a 2D game with isometric view where you controll a single character. The game lets you interact with almost any object in the game, has some kind of crafting system, a story, hack&slay-like battles, a character system where your class only defines your starting skills but everything else is completely open to you. You have moral choices, influence on other characters depending on your choices, different possibilities to solve (or not solve) quests, guilds that you can join, conflicts to solve and a world to save from a great plot of ancient evil powers.It is a game from 2003, so don't expect too much from the graphics, but everything else can compete against most recent games. Divine Divinity was the first part of the Divinity-series (followed by Beyond Divinity, Divinity II (which was obviously the third part) and Divinity: Original Sin and the Spin-Off Divinity: Dragon Commander) and still I think it was the best part of the series.What you can await from this game? Well, at least around 30 hours of gameplay if you only go for the main story. Some very hard and frustrating fights in the beginning of the game, a lot possibilities to break quests or even the game by doing stupid things you are not supposed to do (so keep some different save-files...) and some mad humor when you are least awaiting it. The game requires a bit of skill and intelligent planning. If you have difficulties, it is no shame to rely on a guide on for example which are the skills that are worth upgrading or which things you definitly should not do to not break important quests, but it is also much fun strolling around and experiment.Do I recommend the game? Yes, if you have some frustration tolerance. The price tag is always worth it.

												Dungeon-crawling RPG, along the same lines as the original Diablo but quite a bit bigger.  You will do some "fetch" quests and some monster-slaying quests for the local people, who will reward you with experience points, cash, and equipment.  You will spend a lot of time fighting monster mobs looking for experience to level-up, and you will be checking corpses and containers for health potions and bigger/badder weapons.  You have a choice of male or female from the classic character archetypes (rogue, fighter, wizard) and each of them has some utility.  The fighter can carry high weight and do big damage from swords and axes... makes the beginning of the game easier.  The mage obviously can cast some devastating spells to wipe out the enemy, but has low survivability and really is harder in the beginning and easier in the late stages of the game.  The rogue uses lighter weapons and armor, combined with speed... good with a bow.  I have not yet played as the rogue though so I won't say anything about how easy or hard it is.  One thing I don't like about this one and its sequel is that once you kill something or open a box it stays dead or opened.  So you are very limited in opportunities to get experience/level-ups and items.  Other than that, this game is lots of fun if you're into dungeon-crawler RPG.Unlike Diablo, you actually travel considerably in this game.  You start in a small village, which has a "baby dungeon" below it.  From there, you travel through a forest (inhabited by a bunch of Orcs) and across a bridge (which of course is guarded by Trolls) to reach the part of the world where you will do most of your adventuring.  You have to survive in the wilderness as you travel between several towns and castles, as well as into the sewers and a few other types of dungeons below them.  The story behind the game is pretty interesting, although it's not really great... typical plot for RPG's of the time:  you are "the chosen one" and you have to bring the various races together (elf, orc, dwarf, human) to fight against a greater evil.  You'll be aided by a crazy wizard named Zandalor among other characters.  The side-quests are actually more interesting than the main story, although several of them have you running halfway around the world two or three times in order to complete them.

												Well, what is Divine Divinity?It is the prove that a hack&slay-style gameplay doesn't mean that you can't have a deep and long story with true roleplaying. It is the prove that choosing a class for your character in an rpg doesn't need to limit your further character development. It is the prove that you can have story, the freedom of choice, open world AND action in one game. And it is the prove that mad magicians can invent words even imps can't pronounce properly...Well, Divine Divinity is a 2D game with isometric view where you controll a single character. The game lets you interact with almost any object in the game, has some kind of crafting system, a story, hack&slay-like battles, a character system where your class only defines your starting skills but everything else is completely open to you. You have moral choices, influence on other characters depending on your choices, different possibilities to solve (or not solve) quests, guilds that you can join, conflicts to solve and a world to save from a great plot of ancient evil powers.It is a game from 2003, so don't expect too much from the graphics, but everything else can compete against most recent games. Divine Divinity was the first part of the Divinity-series (followed by Beyond Divinity, Divinity II (which was obviously the third part) and Divinity: Original Sin and the Spin-Off Divinity: Dragon Commander) and still I think it was the best part of the series.What you can await from this game? Well, at least around 30 hours of gameplay if you only go for the main story. Some very hard and frustrating fights in the beginning of the game, a lot possibilities to break quests or even the game by doing stupid things you are not supposed to do (so keep some different save-files...) and some mad humor when you are least awaiting it. The game requires a bit of skill and intelligent planning. If you have difficulties, it is no shame to rely on a guide on for example which are the skills that are worth upgrading or which things you definitly should not do to not break important quests, but it is also much fun strolling around and experiment.Do I recommend the game? Yes, if you have some frustration tolerance. The price tag is always worth it.

												This game is tons of fun.  It's made by the same people who made Divinity: Original Sin, and the same sense of humor is in this game. You can easily double your base stats this way.  Also, don't invest points in magic, as you can buy magic skill books, and you will have a ton of money as you progress.If you like ARPGs, quests that can be long and hard to figure out sometimes, a bunch of freedom, and a huge open world to explore and develop your character in any way you can imagine, then this game is for you.  It's one of my all-time favorites.

												An incredibly enthralling and rewarding experience. Very long to play through, but never feels repetitive or grindy (monsters don't respawn). Works great in Ultrawide HD (2560x1080), which is no small feat for a game this old.There is a few things you should know before you start playing the game.1. BUCK daggers. There is very low variety of dagger weapons, so if you want to rely on assassin's kiss you will be under-powered most of the time. Besides, you can't dual wield, and pairing a shield as high as your shoulder with a dinky dagger makes you look like a retard.2. Craft magic potions to heal yourself. Using the Restoration skill is a lot more resource efficient and handy in combat than chugging healing potions. You will find enough of the latter to use in emergency when your health is too low.3. Skills in the game can be raised three ways- points from leveling up, items (in the form of a skill book) and quest rewards. There are several quests that reward you Restoration, and a book of it you can find at an easy place, so don't waste points maxing it out (max level is 5).4. If you want to reach ALL the loot, you will find the Telekinesis skill useful (I could only retrieve the aforementioned Restoration book with a level 2 Telekinesis skill).5. Scorpion traps are absolutely OP.  Just throw a couple of them at any boss (by using the trap skill) and they will most likely kill it for you.6. Gold will be plentiful. Ignore the Trading skill.7. Save the game often, in different slots. 8. Regeneration is useless. Don't bother. It's too slow to be worth the points and you'll get plenty of potions anyway.

												Like Diablo 2 but looking for something with more depth in the world?  Divine Divinity offers a massive and seamless open world (no linear path progression).  You can move and stack objects, choose any skill from any class right from the beginning, go on more sidequests than you can handle, and deeper crafting and alchemy.  It also has an extremely detailed world where you can interact with nearly every single item you see.  Go into someones out and you can do something with every tiny object on the table for example.  Be warned, players may need a notepad to keep track of quest givers as their is no quest tracking.
